courseTitle: Animal Behavior: Stimulus Response in Isopods

pageData.text: This lab investigates the locomotor and <button class='glossary-text'>orientation</button> behavior of isopods based on response to various stimuli. Activity 1 is a general observation of isopod behavior. Activity 2 is an experiment designed to test isopod locomotor response to humid vs. dry environments. Activity 3 has students design their own experiments to test isopod behavior in response to a selected environmental <button class='glossary-text'>variable</button> using scientific method inquiry.

text: Tap water
Timer
Graphing software or a sheet of graph paper

Required for the storage of isopods (disregard if the isopods will be used within a few hours of arrival):

  • Slice of a potato or an apple
  • Hole puncher

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Observe and identify isopod behavior based on movement.
Analyze the effects of humidity on isopod <button class='glossary-text'>orientation</button>.
Design an experiment using the scientific method to analyze the effects of an altered stimuli on isopod behavior.

pageData.text:
Humans have long tried to figure out how animals think; now, advances in robotics are allowing them to study animal behavior in a whole new way. For example, bees returning from foraging perform a specific set of movements to give directions to the rest of the hive about where to find food, but it has been difficult for scientists to figure out exactly what each motion means. So, a group of researchers designed a robotic bee that could be programmed to perform certain movements1. By observing the responses of the live bees to each action, the researchers are collecting the first key information to interpret bee communication.On the flip side, observing animal behavior is also helping scientists develop better robots2. By observing animals, these engineers hope to make their robots have more realistic body movements and mimic animal body language to make them less intimidating. Other teams are looking at how to mimic animal learning and response to stimuli to make robots more autonomous in remote locations, such as other planets or the deep ocean. 1Holmes, B. (2021, November 8). How scientists are using robotic animals to learn about real ones. Smithsonian.
https://www.smithsonianmag.com/innovation/how-scientists-are-using-robotic-animals-to-learn-about-real-ones-180979017/.2Scharping, N. (2019, December 5). Meet the roboticist making machines act like animals. Discover Magazine.
https://www.discovermagazine.com/technology/meet-the-roboticist-making-machines-act-like-animals.

pageData.subTitle: Animal Behavior and Stimuli Responses
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Ethology</button> is the science of animal behavior. Behavior of an animal can be defined as everything an animal does and how it does it. Generally, when ethologists study animal behavior, they are interested in muscular responses—whether this be when an anole lizard puffs out its throat when reacting to danger or when a dog’s hair stands up on its back when it has become nervous or startled. However, nonmuscular actions, such as when an organism camouflages itself to avoid predators, are studied for behavioral purposes in animals as well.

<button class='glossary-text'>Stimulus response</button> focuses on mechanisms that trigger different behaviors. This response in animals can come from environmental stimuli or genetic, physiological, or anatomical triggers. The variety of stimuli that organisms react to can be classified as internal and external. An example of an external stimulus response is when birds migrate south for the winter. Their bodies need warmer weather to survive; when the weather gets colder, the behavioral response is to migrate south to, generally, warmer conditions. If you have ever seen a dog vomit, this is the internal stimulus response to having possibly ingested something poisonous or having an infection or illness. All organisms encounter a variety of stimuli, and their bodies have to create a balance to account for this alteration, which is known as <button class='glossary-text'>homeostasis</button>.
A common example is when an organism regulates its body temperature. Without this regulation, an organism would cease to survive, so its body must adapt to the stimuli accordingly.</button>

Many behaviors involve locomotion, or directed movement, of the animal within its environment. In this lab, you will investigate some innate (inherited, as opposed to learned) locomotor behaviors of isopods. Looking at <button class='glossary-text'>orientation</button> will show how both genes and environmental factors influence behavior.

pageData.subTitle: Directed Movements
pageData.text: Orientation is the process by which animals position themselves in relation to the spatial features of their environments. <button class='glossary-text'>Taxis</button> is the oriented movement of an animal relative to a stimulus. The animal may turn away from, toward, perpendicular to, or parallel to the stimulus. The turning may or may not be followed by a corresponding movement of the animal in relation to the stimulus. <button class='glossary-text'>Kinesis</button> is random, undirected movement, with a change in the rate of movement or the rate of turning, of an animal in response to a stimulus.

Consider the following experiment: a researcher places a dead, decomposing mouse in the center of a test surface with an area of one square meter. The researcher then places a carrion beetle (an insect that eats dead animal tissue) somewhere on the test surface and observes. The beetle crawls forward for three seconds, turns, crawls in a different direction for three seconds, and continues in this manner. The researcher concludes that the beetle is moving randomly in relation to the dead mouse. Continued observation reveals that the beetle crawls faster and covers more ground when it happens to turn in the direction of the dead mouse. In addition, the beetle crawls slowly and covers less ground when it happens to crawl away from the mouse. In this way, the beetle’s random movements will bring it to the dead mouse. This is an example of <button class='glossary-text'>kinesis</button>.

<button class='glossary-text'>Agonistic</button> behaviors are aggressive or submissive displays. A common example is a cat’s response to an aggressive dog. The cat fluffs its fur and stands sidewise relative to the dog. These behaviors make the cat appear larger and stronger than it really is.

Isopods are crustaceans that inhabit nearly all environments and include marine and terrestrial species. Terrestrial isopods are the land-dwelling crustaceans commonly known as sow bugs (Porcellio laevis) and pill bugs (Armadillidium vulgare). Relatives of lobsters, crabs, and shrimp, these terrestrial isopods breathe with gills, which must remain moist to function effectively. Although pill bugs and sow bugs are of different species, they are similar in size, color, and life cycle.

When threatened, pill bugs curl up into a tight ball for protection (Figure 1) whereas sow bugs either flee or remain perfectly still and play dead, which are both examples of agonistic behaviors. In this investigation, you will analyze different environmental factors that may cause kineses or taxes in isopods.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A pill bug (Armadillidium granulatum) in various stages of conglobulation, or rolling up.

pageData.question: A pill bug curling up when threatened is an example of which of the following behaviors?

options.text: agonistic behavior
taxis
kinesis
orienting behavior
ethological behavior

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Pill bugs curling up into a tight ball for protection is an agonistic behavior.

pageData.question: Which of the following behaviors is an example of taxis?

options.text: An earthworm burrows under the soil when exposed to a bright light.
A dog paces in the garden waiting for its owner to come home.
A fruit fly flies randomly around a kitchen, landing occasionally on various surfaces.
Some birds of the same species lay 2 eggs while others lay 3 eggs.
Fish develop abnormally in a stream that is polluted with industrial run-off.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Taxis is the oriented movement of an animal relative to a stimulus. The animal may turn away from, toward, perpendicular to, or parallel to the stimulus.

The turning may or may not be followed by a corresponding movement of the animal in relation to the stimulus. Kinesis is random, undirected movement, with a change in the rate of movement or the rate of turning, of an animal in response to a stimulus. Agonistic behaviors are aggressive or submissive displays. A common example is a cat’s response to an aggressive dog. The cat fluffs its fur and stands sidewise relative to the dog. These behaviors make the cat appear larger and stronger than it really is. When threatened, pill bugs curl up into a tight ball for protection whereas sow bugs either flee or remain perfectly still and play dead, which are both examples of agonistic behaviors.

pageData.subTitle: Scientific Method Inquiry
pageData.text: When performing any type of scientific evaluation, the scientific method is very useful in obtaining accurate results. This method involves performing experiments and recording observations to answer a question of interest. When manipulating different <button class='glossary-text'>variables</button> to see their effects on the motion of the isopods in the following experiments, you will be implementing the scientific method to understand how different factors produce these effects. To do this, a few very important steps are required. The first is forming a testable <button class='glossary-text'>hypothesis</button>, or an educated prediction of what one expects to observe based on previous knowledge on the subject. In Activity 1, you are asked to make general observations of isopods without any outside factors playing into their behavior. In the second and third activities, different variables are altered so that the isopods’ <button class='glossary-text'>orientation</button> and general stimuli responses can be analyzed.

Variables are factors that are relevant to the question that is being asked. When designing an experiment, only one variable is changed at a given time. There are three types of variables in a given experiment. The <button class='glossary-text'>independent variable</button> is the factor hypothesized to produce the effect under investigation. This variable can be measured and is often controlled by the investigator. Some common independent variables are time, temperature, concentration, and pressure.

also are measurable, but their values are dependent on the independent variables. An easy way to think about the independent and dependent variables is with the following statement: “If I change the independent variable from X to Y, what will happen to the dependent variable?” A scientist will control the rate of change of the independent variable and observe the resulting change in the dependent variable. The third type of variable is a , which includes all other non-independent and non-dependent variables. Controlled variables should remain unchanged while the independent variable is manipulated. The controlled variable is not part of the results, but if changes during an experiment, it may invalidate the results.

pageData.question: A researcher performs an experiment to investigate which food isopods will eat the most. The materials list includes a choice chamber, apple slices, orange peels, potato cubes, and isopods. Which item in the materials list is the controlled variable?

options.text: choice chamber
apple slices
orange peels
potato cubes
isopods

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: In this example, a choice chamber is the controlled variable. The controlled variable is not part of the results, but if it changes during an experiment, it may invalidate the results.

pageData.question: A researcher designs an experiment to determine if the temperature in the room influences how much apple isopods will eat. Twenty isopods are placed with apple slices in rooms at 10 °C, 20° C, and 30 °C. What is the independent variable?

options.text: temperature
how much apple is eaten
the isopods
the researcher
the number of rooms

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Some common independent variables are time, temperature, concentration, and pressure.

An easy way to think about the independent and dependent variables is with the following statement: “If I change the independent variable from X to Y, what will happen to the dependent variable?” A scientist will control the rate of change of the independent variable and observe the resulting change in the dependent variable. The third type of variable is a controlled variable, which includes all other non-independent and non-dependent variables. Controlled variables should remain unchanged while the independent variable is manipulated.

pageData.desc:
A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. Before beginning this investigation, prepare a holding container and transfer the isopods to it.
In Activity 1, you will observe the isopods and document their behavior.
In activity 2, you will put filter paper in each side of the choice chamber and add water to 1 side. Then, you will transfer the isopods to both sides of the choice chamber and record the number on each side every 30 seconds for 10 minutes.
In activity 3, you will design your own experiment using the isopods. Then, you will perform the experiment and evaluate the results.

pageData.text: Reorder Information:Replacement supplies for the Animal Behavior: Stimulus Response in Isopods investigation can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company, item 580142.Call: 866-332-4478 to order.

pageData.subTitle: Acclimating and Holding Isopods
pageData.text: Immediately upon receipt of the isopods, open the shipping container and check the condition of the animals. The isopods are shipped in damp paper towels to provide the humidity they require. If you will need to hold your isopods for more than a few hours after arrival, close the container and prepare a holding pail from a disposable plasticware container. Punch airholes in the lid of the holding pail. Place a cup of moist soil in the bottom of the pail. Place leaf litter and, if possible, a slice of raw potato or apple on the soil. Dampen the inside of the pail with room temperature tap water. Place the shipping container in the pail, and empty the contents onto the bottom of the pail. Remove the shipping container. Gently unfold the crumpled, moist paper towel, and shake off as many isopods as possible. If you are unable to dislodge all the isopods, leave the paper towel in a loose tangle in the pail and replace the lid. Leave the pail in a cool dark place for at least an hour. The isopods should leave the paper towel and move to the potting soil. Use a sorting brush to remove any that remain on the towel. Mist the inside of the pail again, and replace the lid. The isopods can be held like this for several hours or overnight. Remove any food that becomes moldy during this time.

text: Read through all the activities.
Obtain all necessary materials.
When you are ready to begin the experiment, place the isopods in Petri dishes along with a small amount of substrate such as damp potting soil or leaf litter.

pageData.text: Read all instructions for this investigation before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) described in this section and the Activity section.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing these activities. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing each activity. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is an example of an internal stimulus response?

options.text: An animal eats because it feels hungry.
An animal turns away from bright light to protect its eyes.
An animal moves into a warmer area because the air temperature is cool.
An animal flees from a loud noise.
An animal hides to avoid a predator.

assestmentData.question: Which term is used for the oriented movement of an animal relative to a stimulus?

options.text: taxis
homeostasis
kinesis
avoidance
agonistic

assestmentData.question: Which term is used for random, undirected movement of an animal relative to a stimulus?

options.text: kinesis
homeostasis
avoidance
taxis
agonistic

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is agonistic behavior?

options.text: A dog cowers when approached by a large, noisy stranger.
A cat purrs as she dozes in the sunlight.
A honeybee "dances" to signal to other bees the location of nearby flowers.
A squirrel buries acorns in the ground.
A chameleon changes its skin color to match the tree on which it climbs.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the goal of Activity 1 in this investigation?

options.text: to observe isopod behavior without any outside factors
to observe how humidity impacts isopod behavior
to observe how temperature impacts isopod behavior
to observe the preferred isopod food source
to observe the preferred mating environment for isopods

assestmentData.question: Which of the following items will you need to supply yourself to complete this investigation?

options.text: graphing materials
sow bugs
distilled water
construction paper
coffee filters

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes a dependent variable?

options.text: Its value depends on that of another variable.
It is changed at regular intervals by the investigator.
It is one's pervious knowledge of a subject being investigated.
Its value is controlled by the investigator.
It is the time spent conducting an experiment.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes an independent variable?

options.text: It is the factor hypothesized to produce the effect under investigation.
It is the variable that is measured by the investigator.
It should remain unchanged throughout an experiment.
It is an educated prediction of the results of an experiment.
It is a variable that is not measurable.

pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.

In Activity 1, you will observe isopods and document their behavior. You will then identify any agonistic behaviors and determine whether the isopod movements were examples of <button class='glossary-text'>taxis</button> or <button class='glossary-text'>kinesis</button>.

Observe the isopods undisturbed for 10 minutes. As you observe, make notes about the isopods’ movements in the Lab Notebook. Do they move continuously, or do they settle down between periods of movement? If two isopods come into contact, what happens?

In Activity 2, you will observe isopods in a choice chamber with wet and dry compartments. You will document isopod movement between these chambers and use the data to determine isopod humidity preferences.

pages.title: Activity 2
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Orientation Behavior of Isopods in Reaction to Humidity (6 steps)

pageData.text: Place a clean filter paper disk in each side of the choice chamber.

Using the dropping pipet, saturate the filter paper on one side of the chamber with tap water. Pour off any excess water. Do not let the water run into the other side of the chamber and moisten that paper.
Write a <button class='glossary-text'>hypothesis</button> for what you think will happen once the isopods are introduced into each side of the chamber.
Use the sorting brush to transfer 5 isopods to each side of the chamber. Put on the lids.

Using the timer, count and record in Data Table 1 the number of animals on each side of the chamber every 30 seconds for 10 minutes. Continue to record even if the isopods all move to one side or stop moving.
Graph the data from the Data Table 1 for both the wet and dry sides of the chamber. Title the graph. Plot the on the x-axis and the on the y-axis.
In Activity 3, you will design, perform, and evaluate your own isopod behavior experiment using the choice chamber and a <button class='glossary-text'>variable</button> of your choosing.

pages.title: Activity 3
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Using Knowledge to Design an Experiment (7 steps)

typeBefore.text: In Activity 2, the humidity (moisture) was altered to observe the effects on isopod <button class='glossary-text'>orientation</button>. In this activity, use your knowledge of isopod behavior to design an experiment by altering a different environmental <button class='glossary-text'>variable</button>. A few examples of factors to alter include temperature (cool vs. warm) or light (light vs. dark). Be creative, and use another idea you may have as well.
In designing and carrying out your experi-ment, take care to avoid injuring the isopods. For example, lamps placed too close to the animals may generate dangerously high temperatures.

pageData.text: In the Lab Notebook, state the variable to be altered (<button class='glossary-text'>independent variable</button>) along with the dependent and <button class='glossary-text'>controlled variables</button>.

Based on your laboratory experience with isopods, state a <button class='glossary-text'>hypothesis</button> for your experiment. Your hypothesis should include the conditions tested, the expected outcome, and a reason for the expected outcome.
List the materials needed for the experiment.
List the step-by-step procedure to be followed.
Describe the data that will be collected and how the results will be displayed.
Perform the experiment. Record and analyze your data.
State your conclusions in terms of the hypothesis tested.

text: After the lab is completed, do not release the isopods into the environment. Dispose of them in plastic bags, and freeze them for a minimum of 3 days. Then discard the bag in the regular trash.
Rinse and dry the lab equipment, and return the materials to your equipment kit.
Clean and sanitize the work space.

Write a hypothesis for what you think will happen once the isopods are introduced into each side of the chamber.

text: State your conclusions in terms of the hypothesis tested in Activity 3.
Based on the results obtained in Activities 1, 2, and 3, what type of environment do isopods appear to prefer?
Would you expect to find isopods anywhere near your home? If so, where?

Imagine that a biologist deposits 50 isopods on the surface of the leaf litter in a forest. The back of each isopod is marked with a dot of paint for identification purposes. The biologist departs, then returns one hour later and attempts to retrieve as many of the isopods as possible. Where will most of the isopods likely be found and why?

data.title: Agnostic
data.content: Describes behaviors that are aggressive or submissive displays

data.title: Controlled variable
data.content: A variable that is not independent or dependent and should remain unchanged throughout the experiment

data.title: Dependent variable
data.content: The variable that is measured and whose values are dependent on the those of the independent variable

data.title: Homeostasis
data.content: The process of self-regulation by which biological systems tend to maintain stability while adjusting to conditions that are optimal for survival

data.title: Hypothesis
data.content: An educated assumption or prediction of what one expects to observe; the predicted results of an experiment

data.title: Independent variable
data.content: The variable hypothesized to produce the effect under investigation

data.title: Orientation
data.content: The process by which animals position themselves in relation to the spatial features of their environments

data.title: Taxis
data.content: The oriented movement of an animal relative to a stimulus

data.title: Variable
data.content: A factor that is relevant to a question that is being asked or investigated in an experiment
